A ring (admitting a unit element) is a set R together with two laws of composition written as addition '+' and multiplication '.' such that: (i) R is a commutative group with respect to addition. (ii) R is a monoid with respect to multiplication, i.e., the multiplication is associative, and there exists a unit element in R. (iii) The distributive laws hold, i.e., (a+b) 
cdot c=a 
cdot c+b 
cdot c, and c 
cdot(a+b)=c 
cdot a+c 
cdot b for all a, b, c in R.

An ideal \(\mathfrak{a}\) in a ring \(R\) is called reduced if \(\mathfrak{a} = \operatorname{rad} \mathfrak{a}\), where \(\operatorname{rad} \mathfrak{a}\) is the set of all elements \(a \in R\) such that there exists some \(n \in \mathbb{N}\) with \(a^{n} \in \mathfrak{a}\).
Does the concept of a/an Ring need to be defined for a definition of a/an Reduced ideal to make sense? (True if the first concept is needed and False if is not.)

Explanation: The definition of a reduced ideal explicitly mentions that it is an ideal in a ring R. This implies that the concept of a ring must be established first, as the ideal is defined within the context of a ring. Furthermore, the definition of a reduced ideal involves operations and elements (like the radical of an ideal) that are inherently linked to the structure and properties of a ring. Therefore, without the concept of a ring, the definition of a reduced ideal would not have a meaningful or applicable context.
